Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Micro-Pulse DIAL (MPD) Testbed for Sensing Lower Tropospheric Water Vapor Profiles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed project seeks to further develop and field a Micro-pulse DIAL (MPD) Lidar system. This system will be used by researchers to advance our knowledge in the areas of measuring water vapor concentration and distribution, convective initiation, and land-atmosphere exchange. This new system will potentially advance our ability to better predict weather, particularly in the area of storm development.

The proposed major research instrumentation (MRI) project seeks to develop and make available to the science community a system of five diode-laser-based, micro-pulse, differential absorption lidar (DIAL) instruments for measuring the spatial and temporal distribution of water vapor in the lower atmosphere. The Micro-Pulse DIAL (MPD) instruments will build on the proven design developed by the PI and Co-PI, including development of enclosures to make the system more field deployable and network attachable for remote access. Once the testing phase is complete, the MPD research instrumentation will be made available to the science community through the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) Earth Observing Laboratory (EOL) Facilities and Instrument Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to accurately forecast weather, such as severe storms that can adversely affect transportation, as well as public safety and precipitation patterns that can affect agriculture, as well as provide flood warnings relies on the ability to measure the current state of the atmosphere continuously and in real time.  The scientific community has identified the atmospheric measurements needed to define the state of the atmosphere.  These measurements include the spatial and temporal distribution of water vapor in the lower atmosphere, the spatial and temporal distribution of atmospheric temperature, the stable and capping boundary layer height, and the spatial and temporal distribution of atmospheric winds.  The goal of the National Science Foundation funded project was to develop, demonstrate, and validate a network of remote sensing instruments that can provide long-term continuous measurements of the water vapor in the lower troposphere.  This network of instruments will then be used as a testbed towards improving weather forecasting and better understanding complex atmospheric processes.

     Researchers at Montana State University in collaboration with colleagues at the National Center for Atmospheric Research have developed a network of five remote sensing instruments that are capable of providing the needed measurement of the spatial and temporal distribution of water vapor in the lower troposphere.  These instruments use semiconductor lasers and amplifiers to illuminate the atmosphere.  Light scattered back from air molecules, aerosols (dust, pollen, smoke, particulates), and clouds is collected by a telescope and detected.  By monitoring the collected scattered light, the spatial and temporal distribution of water vapor can be determined.  Furthermore, the instrument architecture provides the future opportunity to also measure temperature, boundary layer height, and wind fields in the lower atmosphere.  The extension to these measurements is ongoing.

     A network of five remote sensing instruments were designed and built in the first stage of the project.  During the second stage of the project, these instruments were tested using a laboratory- based facility to ensure the efficacy of the measurement of spatial distribution of water vapor in the lower troposphere.  Once the data from the laboratory-based instruments were validated, environmental enclosures were built to house the instruments for field deployments in the third stage of the project.  During the final stage of the project, the network of instruments was deployed in the spring and summer of 2020 at a test facility in Oklahoma to ensure these instruments can provide the needed measurements with unattended operation over extended periods of time.  This facility was chosen since it has strong atmospheric measurement capabilities that allowed validation of the data from our new instrument network.  With the field test completed, modifications to the instrument housing were undertaken to improve instrument performance based on lessons learned.  The network of five remote sensing instruments for profiling water vapor in the lower troposphere has been completed and the network of instruments will be maintained and available for the larger scientific community to use through the National Center for Atmospheric Research.  An initial deployment of the network of instruments is planned for the summer of 2021 in Taiwan in support of the atmospheric science community and work has begun using these instruments for improving weather forecasting.
